title: DIY SOS star Nick Knowles on getting rid of 90 per cent of his belongings
text:

There doesn’t seem to be a month that goes by without Nick Knowles being pictured with a mystery lady – often one much younger than him.

And yet ask Nick – who has been single for three years after splitting from second wife Jessica, with whom he shares a son, Eddie, five – about his life away from the cameras and it quickly becomes apparent he is most content at home in the solitude of the Cotswolds countryside.

It’s a far cry from the ladies’ man image he normally gets tagged with.

Nick paints the picture of an idyllic lifestyle, which sees him hunting for dragons in the woods and planting vegetables with Eddie.

‘Home life is good,’ he says.

‘I never talk or comment on my private life, but I am happy.'

'Work is good, too.'

'I am happy bumbling along.'

'I am living where I want to live in the world with a simpler life now.'

(Image: Paul Poynter)

(Image: BBC)

'I moved to a much smaller house and I got rid of 90% of my belongings that I never bothering to look at.'

'It was great.'

'Yesterday is of no interest to me – what is happening tomorrow is.'

'I look back at my old special childhood moments and I can remember happily going to my uncle’s house to pop the pea pods we had grown.'

'I want to recreate those moments for Eddie – It’s not about the expensive things.’

Despite embracing a slower lifestyle, Nick’s work ethic is still second to none.

He has just finished working three weeks back-to-back with no breaks.

‘I am probably going as fast as I was 10 years ago,’ he chuckles.

‘But I think part of it is down to the fact I grew up on a council estate and I always assume it’s going to end tomorrow.'

'I have to look after my family, and so I have to get on with it.’

Nick does his best to ensure work doesn’t take over completely, so he can spend more time with his youngest son.

(Image: James Gourley/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

But like many working parents, the dad of four – Tyrian, 27, Tuesday, 25, Charlie, 23, and Eddie – confides he is constantly wrestling with getting the life/work balance right.

‘When my youngest is around, he is the one who needs to see me the most at the moment,’ says Nick.

‘I like to see the rest of the family as often as I can, too.'

'Every person who works has this dilemma.'

'How much should you work to improve the standard of living for your family versus seeing your kids grow up?’

But it’s having a younger son again that has helped give him a great deal of perspective.

‘I absolutely love my time with all my kids,’ he says.

‘They have all got a great sense of humour – Eddie loves noticing the rainbow colours in a puddle, and it’s nice for me to take the time to stop and look at it, too'.

'The world is the most fantastic theme park, but we are often too busy getting to the next appointment, and end up missing the rides along the way.’

Passionate about many causes, including the Child Bereavement UK charity and those supporting ex-military, Nick says he does feel lucky that all his own children are safe and well – particularly when he experiences first hand the hardship faced by thousands through his Children In Need projects.

‘Of course it makes me hug them more,’ he explains.

‘But I’m also very aware that we are all only a couple of incidents away from our children being in those situations'.

'A big accident or illness could change everything, and suddenly you are the one in that position.'

'When you are in a good position and are able to make a difference, you should.'

'It is very important for me to do that.’

Nick is definitely making a difference for this year’s Children In Need, as he sets about renovating an old Victorian hall in Blackburn and turning it into a centre for young homeless people.

And just as millions of us reach for the tissues every time we watch emotional scenes during his hit series DIY SOS, Nick admits that he often cries, too.

‘I do get emotional,’ he confides.

‘I do it off screen.'

'The programme is about the people who are having the project built for them and the builders/volunteers who have done it.'

'You don’t need a TV presenter bawling!'

(Image: Neil@neilsherwood.com)

'When I do get emotional, I leave the cameras.'

'It’s the people’s moment – not mine.'

'I absolutely love doing the programme as it gives us all a bit of hope that people are nicer than they think they are.'

'Because of our political situation, there is this narrative that we are all against each other.'

'Yet on DIY SOS, everywhere we go, we ask people to work for free and donate for free – this is not a country that has no sense of community.’

And this sense of community, which sees builders give up their free time to drive in from all over the UK just to lend a hand, is the reason why Nick will never stop working on the programme.

‘I get paid a lot more to do the quiz shows than DIY SOS,’ he reveals.

‘But this is the one I don’t want to give up, because I chose to make this type of programme and I want to because it’s important.’

At 57, Nick is also fully aware of the importance of being healthy.

He tends to follow a mostly plant-based diet and tries to go to the gym as much as he can.

‘But I am on my feet all day with DIY SOS, and so that keeps me fairly fit,’ he adds.

(Image: Internet Unknown)

‘I am not fully vegan – I have never gone the whole hog, and do eat some meat, but I try to keep myself in decent nick.’

With a string of other TV hits under his belt, including I’m A Celebrity…Get Me Out Of Here! and Who Dares Wins, Nick shows no sign of slowing down.

He now has a non-exclusive contract with the BBC, which means he can work for other channels.

It’s a prospect that excites him.

With previous forays into music (when he was in the jungle, his cover of Make You Feel My Love topped the charts) and cookbooks, Nick says he would love to make some more history and movie programmes in the future.

So, will he become the male equivalent of Mary Berry and work into his 80s?

He laughs, before pointing out, ‘Billy on DIY SOS is coming up to 70!’

Nick then adds, ‘I will do – as long as the BBC keeps funding DIY SOS and people watch it, then I will make it, because it helps people.'

'But one day I’d also love to go to the middle of nowhere and write…’

We look forward to all those projects very much.

(Image: Neil@neilsherwood.com)

How do he spend his Sunday?

Up with the lark or a lie-in?

There used to be a time where you could set off a weapon outside the house and I wouldn’t wake up!

But when I have Eddie with me, I wake up at the same time as him.

He then sticks his nose on mine and says, ‘What do we need to do?’ and I reply, ‘We need to give each other more space!’

Sunday night telly or a movie?

Sunday night telly for Peaky Blinders.

I am enough of a fan that it has made me dig out my more vintage suits.

When I have my next two weeks off, I am going to shave my hair into a Peaky Blinders haircut!

Fry-up or healthy?

The Knowles’ family scrambled eggs are legendary.

Both my elder sons and I are very adept at making French-style scrambled eggs, which are just fantastic.

A pint or glass of wine?

I don’t drink beer very much.

I am more of a glass of wine person.

I like both white and red equally.

A Sunday roast or a healthy dish?

Definitely a roast on a Sunday.

Catch DIY SOS: The Big Build Children in Need Special on BBC1, Wednesday 13 November
description: The TV presenter, 57, on why he prefers the simple life, crying when the DIY SOS cameras are turned off, and making a difference when he can…
